rawData.period_title: Geological Foundations and the Paleolithic Era
rawData.description: The epoch of archaic hominids and early human migration, characterized by geological volatility and land bridges connecting the archipelago to mainland Asia[cite: 7, 8].

events.title: Arrival of Homo erectus
events.description: Hominids migrate into the archipelago via Sunda Shelf land bridges. Fossils at Sangiran challenge 'Out of Africa' timelines[cite: 10, 11].

events.title: The Sangiran Flourishing
events.description: Dense population of Homo erectus utilizing simple stone tools (flake industry) in a volcanic woodland environment[cite: 15, 16].

events.title: The Ngandong Survivors
events.description: Last known survival of Homo erectus (Solo Man) along the Solo River, coexisting chronologically with other Asian hominids[cite: 17, 18].

events.title: Homo floresiensis (The Hobbit)
events.description: Survival of a distinct, small-statured hominid species on the isolated island of Flores[cite: 20, 21].

events.title: Earliest Cave Art
events.description: Cave paintings in Sulawesi depicting therianthropes hunting pigs, among the oldest figurative art in the world[cite: 26, 27].

rawData.period_title: Austronesian Expansion and the Metal Age
rawData.description: The migration of Austronesian speakers bringing maritime technology, agriculture, and eventually metallurgy, forming the demographic foundation of modern Indonesia[cite: 28, 29].

events.title: Departure from Taiwan
events.description: Austronesian groups move south into the Philippines with advanced maritime technology like crab-claw sails[cite: 31, 32].

events.title: Settlement of the Archipelago
events.description: Migration into Borneo, Sulawesi, and Java, introducing rice cultivation (sawah) and pottery[cite: 33, 37].

events.title: Introduction of Metallurgy
events.description: Bronze casting arrives from Dong Son culture (Vietnam), typified by large ceremonial bronze drums[cite: 39, 40].

rawData.description: The rise of 'Indianized' states adopting Hindu-Buddhist kingship, producing great empires like Srivijaya and Mataram[cite: 45, 47].

events.title: Kutai Inscriptions (Yupa)
events.description: Oldest written records in Indonesia; stone pillars in East Kalimantan celebrating King Mulavarman[cite: 49, 50].

events.title: Tarumanagara Engineering
events.description: King Purnawarman organizes the excavation of the Gomati river (11km) for flood control and irrigation[cite: 56, 58].

events.title: Srivijaya as Buddhist Center
events.description: Chinese monk I-Tsing documents Srivijaya (Palembang) as a major center of learning with over 1,000 monks[cite: 61, 62].

events.title: Construction of Borobudur
events.description: Completion of the massive Mahayana Buddhist stupa by the Sailendra dynasty in Central Java[cite: 73, 75].

events.title: Construction of Prambanan
events.description: The Sanjaya dynasty builds a grand Hindu temple complex dedicated to the Trimurti[cite: 77, 78].

events.title: Chola Raids
events.description: Indian Chola Empire attacks Srivijaya, capturing the Maharaja and shattering the empire's hegemony[cite: 68, 69].

events.title: Rise of Singhasari
events.description: Ken Arok defeats Kediri and establishes the Singhasari dynasty, marking a new era of Javanese power[cite: 89, 90].

rawData.period_title: The Majapahit Empire and the Rise of Islam
rawData.description: The zenith of the classical era under Majapahit and the concurrent spread of Islam via coastal trade routes[cite: 93, 107].

events.title: Founding of Majapahit
events.description: Raden Wijaya defeats invading Mongol forces and establishes the Majapahit empire in East Java[cite: 95, 96].

events.title: The Palapa Oath
events.description: Prime Minister Gajah Mada vows to unify the entire Nusantara archipelago under Majapahit rule[cite: 98, 99].

events.title: Golden Age of Hayam Wuruk
events.description: Majapahit reaches peak influence; the Nagarakretagama is written, detailing the empire's structure[cite: 101, 102].

events.title: Rise of Demak
events.description: Raden Patah founds the Demak Sultanate, the first Islamic power in Java[cite: 114].

events.title: Fall of Majapahit
events.description: The Islamic Sultanate of Demak conquers the Majapahit rump state, ending the Hindu-Buddhist imperial era in Java[cite: 106].

rawData.period_title: The Age of Commerce and Colonial Intrusion
rawData.description: A triangular struggle for control of the spice trade between indigenous Sultanates, Portuguese/Spanish explorers, and the Dutch VOC[cite: 117, 118].

events.title: Fall of Malacca
events.description: The Portuguese capture Malacca, disrupting Asian trade and dispersing merchants to other regional ports[cite: 119, 120].

events.title: Rise of Ternate
events.description: Sultan Baabullah expels the Portuguese and expands Ternate's influence over 72 islands[cite: 125, 126].

events.title: Founding of the VOC
events.description: The Dutch East India Company is chartered as the world's first multinational corporation with sovereign rights[cite: 128, 129].

events.title: Founding of Batavia
events.description: Jan Pieterszoon Coen razes Jayakarta and builds Batavia (Jakarta) as the VOC Asian headquarters[cite: 130].

events.title: Banda Islands Genocide
events.description: VOC massacres the population of the Banda Islands to enforce a nutmeg monopoly[cite: 132].

events.title: Siege of Batavia
events.description: Sultan Agung of Mataram attacks Batavia but fails due to Dutch naval power and logistics[cite: 133, 134].

events.title: Treaty of Giyanti
events.description: Mataram is split into Surakarta and Yogyakarta, permanently fracturing Javanese political power[cite: 138, 139].

rawData.period_title: The Colonial State and the Seeds of Nationalism
rawData.description: Transformation from a trading network to a centralized colonial state, followed by the rise of modern Indonesian nationalism[cite: 143, 166].

events.title: Daendels Era / Great Post Road
events.description: Daendels constructs the 1,000km Great Post Road across Java using forced labor[cite: 144, 145].

events.title: The Java War
events.description: Prince Diponegoro leads a massive rebellion against the Dutch, devastating Central Java[cite: 152, 153].

events.title: Cultivation System Implemented
events.description: Forced cultivation of export crops (Cultuurstelsel) restores Dutch finances but causes famine in Java[cite: 155, 156].

events.title: The Ethical Policy
events.description: Dutch policy shift towards Irrigation, Emigration, and Education, inadvertently creating a nationalist elite[cite: 161, 163].

events.title: Budi Utomo Founded
events.description: Establishment of the first modern indigenous organization, celebrated as National Awakening Day[cite: 167].

events.title: The Youth Pledge
events.description: Young nationalists declare the trinity of 'One Motherland, One Nation, One Language'[cite: 172, 173].

rawData.description: The collapse of Dutch rule during WWII, the Japanese occupation, and the violent revolution for sovereignty[cite: 174, 182].

events.title: Dutch Surrender / Japanese Occupation
events.description: Dutch surrender to Japan; beginning of harsh occupation but also military training for Indonesians (PETA)[cite: 176, 179].

events.title: Birth of Pancasila
events.description: Sukarno outlines the five principles of state ideology[cite: 181].

events.title: Proclamation of Independence
events.description: Sukarno and Hatta declare independence in Jakarta[cite: 183].

events.title: Battle of Surabaya
events.description: Fierce resistance against British forces; recognized as Heroes' Day[cite: 185, 188].

events.title: Transfer of Sovereignty
events.description: Dutch recognize Indonesian sovereignty following the Round Table Conference[cite: 195].

rawData.description: The evolution of the modern nation-state through the Old Order, New Order, and the democratic Reformasi era[cite: 197, 217].

events.title: First General Election
events.description: First free democratic election; rise of PKI alarms the military and Islamic groups[cite: 200].

events.title: G30S/PKI Movement
events.description: Failed coup attempt leads to anti-communist purge and the rise of Suharto[cite: 205, 207].

events.title: Supersemar / New Order
events.description: Power transfer to Suharto, beginning 32 years of authoritarian 'New Order' rule[cite: 208, 209].

events.title: Fall of Suharto
events.description: Asian Financial Crisis and student protests force Suharto's resignation, beginning Reformasi[cite: 215, 217].

events.title: Prabowo Presidency
events.description: Prabowo Subianto elected President, representing policy continuity from the Jokowi era[cite: 219, 222].
